results.title: Polka-dotting Royal Exhibition Building
results.brief_description: Hugh McSpeeden is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor festival projections.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.
description_for_label:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.

results.title: A Colour Box
results.brief_description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.
description_for_label: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.

results.title: Bruce Almighty
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Spyglass Entertainment, Tom Shadyac and Jim Carrey
results.brief_description: Local tv reporter Bruce Nolan doesn’t think that the world is treating him fairly. Then, after the worst day ever, Bruce angrily rails against God for ruining his life and mismanaging the universe. So God responds and endows Bruce with all of his powers to see if he can do a better job. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Morgan Freeman, Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, Catherine Bell.

constellations_other.name: Divining the divine
constellations_other.description: Depicting the Almighty in paintings was frowned upon in the early 1800s in Britain, much like it has been throughout the history of cinema, according to writer Scot Hughes, who made many of these connections in a 2003 article in the Sydney Morning Herald.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Universal Pictures, Spyglass Entertainment, Tom Shadyac and Jim Carrey
results.description: Local tv reporter Bruce Nolan doesn’t think that the world is treating him fairly. Then, after the worst day ever, Bruce angrily rails against God for ruining his life and mismanaging the universe. So God responds and endows Bruce with all of his powers to see if he can do a better job. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Morgan Freeman, Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, Catherine Bell.

results.title: Random guy welcomes American protagonist
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @paharikawa's TikTok post
results.brief_description: TikTokker, Aslan Pahari, satirical take on the depiction of non-white characters in mainstream films
results.description: Hollywood has a long history of perpetuating stereotypes and appropriating cultures. Aslan Pahari – known for his satirical anthropological content – skewers the noble and wise Middle Eastern guide who typically leads American ‘heroes’ through supposedly ‘exotic’ lands. By combining tired tropes of Arabic culture – sand dunes, ‘wobbly air’, ‘traditional’ singing – he exposes Hollywood’s uniformed attitude towards non-white characters. Recently, Arabic and Islamic imagery and language was appropriated in Dune (2021), yet the film featured no Middle Eastern or North African actors. By including videos from other users calling out stereotypes, Pahari also demonstrates there’s no single way to represent a people or culture.
description_for_label: Hollywood has a long history of perpetuating stereotypes and appropriating cultures. Here, Aslan Pahari skewers the noble and wise guide in supposedly ‘exotic’ locales. By combining tired cinema tropes of Arab culture, he exposes Hollywood’s uniformed attitude towards non-white characters. Recently, Arabic imagery and language was appropriated in Dune (2021), yet the film featured no Middle Eastern or North African actors. Pahari also demonstrates there’s no single way to represent a people or culture by including videos from other users lampooning stereotypes.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

details.label: Materials
display_values: Digital screen recording of @paharikawa's TikTok post

results.title: 'A'
results.creator_credit: Argos Films Borresholm, Jan Lenica and Renate Duhr
results.brief_description: A bitter, pessimistic cartoon, showing man’s utter helplessness in the face of forces stronger than himself. A man’s home is invaded by the letter “A”. Guile, flattery, magic, brute strength fail to remove this enemy. He gives up all hope - then discovers that “A” has disappeared. After a period of doubt he is delighted to be alone again. Suddenly “B” appears! In fine line pen-and-ink style reminiscent of 19th century engraving, Jan Lenica has created a visual joke based on one of Eugene Ionesco’s quotations. The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)

constellations_primary.name: Make it cute, make them think
constellations_primary.description: Cartoons and anime are known for their dynamic and vibrant visuals, but beneath the cuteness they can also deliver powerful environmental messages and address the climate crisis.

results.title: Shaun Tan's The Lost Thing: From book to film. The Interviews
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’ tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeon holes.
Melbourne-based production company Passion Pictures Australia invited Shaun to direct an animated version of ‘The Lost Thing’, and several years later, the Oscar®-winning short film emerged.
The ACMI exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From book to film’(showing in Gallery Two from 16th July 2013 to 19th January 2014), features Shaun’s exquisite original drawings and working sketches alongside exclusive footage of the animators and sound artists, demonstrating how the drawings were brought to life on screen with movement, sound effects, music and narration.
These eight interview segments are each based on a particular production process in the making of ‘The Lost Thing’.
The eight segments feature interviews with Shaun Tan (writer/co director), Sophie Byrne (producer), Tom Bryant (3D artist), Leo Baker (animator), John Kassab (sound designer) and Michael Yezerski (composer).
In addition to the interviews, there is a wealth of ‘behind-the-scenes’ footage, rough drafts of designs and animation wireframes from the very early stages of production.
